Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: I want to thank all of you thoughtful BCO members who took the time to send me cards of sympathy during this most difficult time for myself and my family. Mom's service was beautiful.  I flew her back to "Sweet Home Alabama", to be laid to rest under a huge Southern Live Oak Tree.  Family members flew in from all over the U.S., and her four Grandsons and two Great-Grandsons were the pallbearers.  The service was everything she would have wanted. I am so privilaged to have the honor of knowing all of you, even if it's just online.  You have shown me what true friendship is all about.  I'll continue to check in to see how you are doing, and offer support and help whenever I can. Peggy  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A special thanks. sincitydealer Lynn1

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Hi everybody, My Mom's shoulder hurts on the outside and she also has a lump on the outside of her upper arm.  This all started about 2 weeks ago.  It appears to be in the soft tissue and not in her bone.  She had an x-ray at the orthopedist, and he couldn't see anything in the bone so we're not sure what to think.  Anybody have experience with this? Thanks, Pegy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Shoulder pain and lump on outside upper arm sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Mom had her first treatment of Halaven yesterday and a prior infusion of the evil Decadron.  When we got home, almost immediately she started complaining of shortness of breath and she said she felt very hot, (no fever).  She was also, what I call, patrolling around the house with her walker.  She can barely walk even with the walker.  I called her Onc's office and they called in a script for Xanax, and that seemed to really help.  My question is what does everybody think caused this?  Decadron or a SE from the Halaven.  I'm leaning toward Decadron, but just not sure.  How long does it take for the SE's of Halaven to kick in? Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Halaven or Decadron? sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom has been throwing up quite a bit lately.  Not sure if it's the Gemzar or liver mets.  She loves to poke around through the second hand stores, but got so sick we had to go home today.  She ended up vomiting in the parking lot as we were leaving then throwing up a lot more when we got home.  She's been throwing up every once and a while for months, but it seems to have gotten much worse in the last 2 or 3 weeks.  It's mostly green or yellow bile.  She's had a lot of heartburn, too.  I just don't know whether it's progression in the liver or Gemzar.   Anybody have an opinion?  She gets Gemzar as a single agent.  She has a while to go before she gets a PET.  She's been sleeping all afternoon.  I'm worried. Peggy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Mom's having a tough time. sincitydealer mthomp2020

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Hello everybody, I'm new here, and I hope somebody can help me.  My 81-year-old mother's cancer has come back.  She was diagnosed in November, stage IV, with mets to liver and bones.  She was stage 1 seven years ago. Anyway, she's been on Taxotere since then, and she now has a bladder infection that won't  clear up.  They've tried two different antibiotics.  She's had it for two weeks. She gets a treatment tomorrow, and is supposed to see her onc.  She doesn't always ask the  questions she should.  Has anybody here had a problem with bladder infections while on chemo?  Do you have any suggestions?  I live far away from my mom, and I'm trying to micro-manage everything from here. I don't want to lose my Momma to some infection or side effect, much less this horrible cancer.  You guys are fighters, and I figure some of you might have experienced the bladder problem at one time or another.  Any advice you could give would be greatly appreciated. I'm praying for my Mother and all of you. Peace, Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: UTI sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Mom is having a PET/CT scan on Monday and a CAT scan with contrast next Thursday.  Now they're throwing in a Colonoscopy on Wednesday for good measure.  She has had a lot of rectal bleeding, but wouldn't the PET or CAT pick it up if there was something wrong there?  That's an awful lot to put an elderly woman through.  If she has hemorrhoids they're really bad bleeders because there's lots of blood.  Could there be something else wrong besides BC spread to her colon?  And if it has spread there, what's the point of such an envasive procedure?  She's already on chemo. Sorry if this is TMI, but I'm just worried about putting her through this just for hemorrhoids. Peggy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: MBCC conference in Miami March 9th through 11th sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom has had such horrible side effects from taxotere they're finally switching her to abraxane.  How many of you guys have been on abraxane?  I hear it's much milder and more effective.  I don't understand why her onc wouldn't have put her on this in the first place. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Switching Mom to Abraxane sincitydealer traciedg

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom has been in agony now for what seems like forever.  Her latest PET scan showed missing bone in her hip/pelvis.  She can't walk anymore without using a walker or a wheelchair.  Even the strongest script for Oxycontin isn't working, and the pain patch has been useless.  Her onc has advised against surgery and so has her regular orthopedist.  The onc wants to send her to a pain specialist, but the only thing my Mom thinks will help her is surgery.   She insists she'll die without it.  I'm afraid she'll die if she has it.  She's 82-years-old so it seems like it would be extra risky.  There's one guy in the area where she lives that does this kind of surgery, so she's going full steam ahead and making an appointment with him to talk about getting it. I know you guys are a lot younger than my Mom, but I was wondering if any of you have had a similar surgery and how it turned out?  I'm so afraid she won't make it off the operating table, and if she does, will she be worse off?  She hasn't seen this doctor yet, and he might not even want to do it, but if he does I just don't know if this is the best decision.  Any input would be appreciated. Thanks, Peggy   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Now I'm really scared. sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: I just don't understand why my mom keeps getting these UTIs.  Last night my step-father had to rush her to the ER because she was unable to go.  She said she was in agony, and she was already on antibiotics which apparently were doing no good.  Just as they got there the dam broke, and she was soaked...kinda like your water breaking right before labor.   I don't think they can figure out why she's getting this stuff.  They just keep giving her antibiotics and send her on her way with no explanation.  She has an appointment with a Urologist on the 11th.  I hope this time they will give her some answers.  This is frustrating to say the least. Could it be that mets are pressing on her bladder or kidneys?  Nothing was ever mentioned about the BC being in either place.  Are those places this type of cancer could spread?  That's fairly uncommon isn't it?. Peggy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Hi everybody, I'm going to my Mom's house for Christmas on December 21st.  I'll be staying long enough to take her for her PET scan and to see her onc on January 5th.  Can anybody give me suggestions for a list of questions I should ask him?  This will be the second time I see him face-to-face, and I want to get as much information as I can for my mom.  They tell her stuff about tumor markers and such, but she doesn't understand any of it.  Any input would be greatly appreciated. Thanks, Peggy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom has a lump on her backside.  It's about 2 to 3 inches away from where she got her last Faslodex injection and about 2 to 3 inches from her spine.  She says it's about an inch in diameter, and it feels like it's under the skin and not in it.  Could this be a reaction from the Faslodex shot or something else?  She says it's real hard but doesn't hurt.  Anybody else had an experience with anything like this?  Are there any nodes in that area? Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lump on Mom's rear end sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: I feel like I just stepped into a nightmare.  As many of you know my Mom has stage lV BC in her liver and bones.  Last Thursday, she called me in tears because her husband that she's been married to for a couple of years suddenly decided to walk out on her.   My cousin had to stay with my Mom until my sister could drive down.  My Mom can no longer be left alone.  She needs constant care. I will be flying down there Tuesday to pick her up and bring her here to Las Vegas to live with me.  I just hope I can find a good doc here who takes Medicare.  My Brother and his family will be moving into her house, but that's another story.  I would feel much better if she's out here with me.  I just don't trust him to do the things I think he should do.  Her tumor markers are on the rise, and I'm not happy with the medical care she's getting there. This couldn't come at a worse time as I'm in the middle of a move myself.  We sold our house and have to be out by the end of August.  In fact it will be two moves because we have to wait for our tenants to move out of our rental property.  That means moving into a 2 bedroom apartment for about 5 months. How could this old geezer do this to my 83-year-old Mother?  Whatever happened to "In sickness and in health"?  This whole thing is making me sick to my stomach.  I'm sorry to be venting here.  I'm in tears as I type this.  I'm crying not for myself, but for her, and all that she has to go through. Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Welcome to my soap opera life. sincitydealer steelrose

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom was put on Xeloda a few months back and it almost killed her...very bad reaction.  I asked her new Onc about it, and he said it was because of some enzyme.  I can't remember whether he said my Mom lacked it or had it because I was so worried about her leg thing at the time.  He said he was treating one lady who is 99 years old with Xeloda, and she's had no problems at all. Does anybody know whether it's the enzyme that causes problems or the lack of it? Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Xeloda Question sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: One dose of Halaven, and she can no longer function!  Major, major fatigue.  It started to hit her yesterday afternoon.  She just can't stay awake.  Has this happened to anybody else?  Any suggestions as to what can be done?  How long does it last? This is no kind of life! Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: HELP! My Mother is a Zombie! sincitydealer 3katz

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Mom's out of the hospital.  They sent a nurse over tonight to train me to flush her port and give her the antibiotics.  Then I have to give her an lV drip for an hour.  Then more flush and heparin.  This happens twice a day.  Tomorrow I do it myself in the morning.  The nurse will be back tomorrow night, but then I think I'm on my own.  The nurse said it's the worst case of cellulitis she's ever seen.  I sure hope I do this right.  They're putting a lot of trust in me.  No wonder the doctor just smiled when I asked who was going to do all this.  Scary! Peggy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: For the last two days I've received several PMs with the subject line, "This Could Save Your Life".  Each of these PMs have a different screen ID.  Is there any way the moderators can stop these people/persons, or is deleting them all we can do?  They all say the same thing in the body of the PM, and I'm sure it's a scam.  Who knows if what they're telling you to do is even safe while on treatment!  Has anybody else gotten them?  I've received three within 24 hours. Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anybody else getting unwanted PMs? sincitydealer Moderators

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Looks like my Mom might not be having surgery after all.  The orthopedist wants to take a wait and see approach.  He's going to see her in about six weeks.  She did say she felt better today, but I'm not sure whether she's really healing or it's the new, stronger script for Oxycontin. Meanwhile, it looks like I might be the one having surgery.  Went to see my orthopedist, and he thinks I've torn the cartilage in my left knee.  He's scheduling me for an MRI.  It's all swollen. Knowing my Mom isn't going to have such major surgery (at least for now), is really a relief.  I was so afraid.  I pray she really is healing. Thanks for reading. Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breathing a sigh of relief sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom didn't even get through the first low dose cycle of Xeloda.  She's having horrendous SEs....open sores in her mouth, fatigue, explosive bloody diarrhea, and the beginning of hand and foot....just about every SE you can get from that medicine.  Is there any chemo that has few to little SEs?  Anything an elderly woman can take?  The anti-hormonals didn't work for her.  All she has is chemo.  Thanks for any input. Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mom can't take Xeloda sincitydealer 3katz

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: My Mom had her PET scan the 5th of January, and her follow up onc appointment on the 17th.  The Femara failed.  She's still waiting for Medicare and supplemental approval for Xeloda.  First the onc's office got the ball rolling.  Then Medicare/Secure Horizons mailed her a bunch of papers to fill out and take to her onc's office so they could fill out some of it.  Then she had to wait almost a week before she could go back and pick up the finished paperwork only to mail it off again to some Government/insurance bureaucrat.  Meanwhile, she's been on no treatment whatsoever with major progression in her liver.  Exactly how long does it take for approval?  WTF! Peggy  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: GOOD GRIEF! How long does it take for insurance approval? sincitydealer sincitydealer

Posts.Content: sincitydealer wrote: Just talked to 2 of my mom's doctors, her onc yesterday and her onc radiologist today.  Her regular onc is saying her last PET scan was stable and no evidence of metabolic activity, and he was very pleased, but he didn't know she is now in a wheelchair and no longer able to walk.  Her next PET is September 25th.  She gets them every 3 months.  I talked to her radiologist this morning after he did a procedure on her.  I asked him if she will ever get out of the chair and he said he didn't know since her pelvis is so riddled with disease and the fractures are not healing like they should.  Since she seems to be getting worse, I came out and asked him the question.   He says she has about 3 to 6 months.  I got a similar bad prognosis from her orthopedist about 2 months ago.  How could 3 doctors have such different answers?  I wonder if these guys talk to each other at all?  I just don't know what to think. Peggy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Who do I believe? sincitydealer sincitydealer

Peggy Log in to post a reply
